title: 108_s286
content: SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. The "Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities Prevention Act of 2003" establishes the National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities to conduct research and promote prevention of such defects and disabilities. The "Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities Prevention Act of 2003" aims to establish a National Spina Bifida Program and gather information on birth defects, developmental disabilities, and health status among individuals with disabilities. It also focuses on reducing suffering from the nation's most common permanently disabling birth defect. Subsection (b) is removed, and subsection (d) is revised to include data on the incidence and prevalence of these conditions and their impact on infant mortality and quality of life. The "Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities Prevention Act of 2003" includes provisions for gathering information on individuals living with birth defects and disabilities, their health status, disparities experienced, and recommendations for improving their quality of life. It also summarizes recommendations from birth defects research conferences sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities Prevention Act of 2003 includes technical corrections for State Councils on Developmental Disabilities, such as redesignating subsections and transferring advisory committee members to advise the National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities. Funding provisions are also adjusted for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities Prevention Act of 2003 makes technical corrections for State Councils on Developmental Disabilities, adjusting funding provisions for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The amendments to Section 122(a) of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 take effect on October 1, 2003, and apply to allotments starting in fiscal year 2004. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to specific committees within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The report will focus on surveillance activities related to the Children's Health Act of 2000, including details on current grantees, data collection, analysis, sources of data, and parental consent compliance. The report required by the Children's Health Act of 2000 must include an analysis of current sources of data for autism and developmental disabilities surveillance, research methods, the need to include education records in surveillance, and parental consent compliance. The report mandated by the Children's Health Act of 2000 should cover the use of education records in surveillance for autism and developmental disabilities, challenges in obtaining these records without consent, and strategies to overcome these challenges and increase parental or patient consent rates. The report mandated by the Children's Health Act of 2000 should include specific justifications for any recommendations for changes to existing statutory authority, such as the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974, without the need for parental or patient consent.
